text: Okay folks, just going to keep it real on this one,
we wanted an excuse to look at dog videos
all day and this is the result.
It’s time for some K9 chem.
(Reactions Splash)
As some of you out there have already learned,
dogs have an outstanding sense of smell and
an olfactory system that runs laps around ours.
With over 220 million olfactory receptors
On their noses, dogs can do more than
just sniff their neighbor’s butt.
In fact, a dog’s nose is so strong that
it can detect diseases in people.
One clinical trial had dogs sniffing out prostate
cancer in the urine of patients with 98% accuracy.
That’s not all, some service dogs are
trained to sniff out explosives, drugs,
and even different species of insects.
Now finding a bomb ought to make you
sweat dogs on the other hand start sweating
in order to find the bomb.
When dogs get hot, they don’t sweat like humans.
Instead, they have glands on the bottoms
of their paws and their noses that keep
their body temperatures regulated.
But the mucus on a dog’s nose also helps
them sift through and process smells.
When a dog smells something, molecules
enter into their olfactory system and bind to
receptor cells that send a signal to the brain like,
“hey this is poop” or “hey it’s that thing
I’m supposed to smell to get a treat!
Nose mucus slows down or speeds up specific types
of molecules, helping a dog’s olfactory system
process and identify smells more efficiently.
Speaking of smells, why is it that dogs reek
immediately after they’ve had a bath?
That wet dog smell is from the microorganisms
that live in dog fur like yeasts and bacteria.
These organisms excrete stinky, volatile compounds.
So if these compounds are always being produced
on your pet, why does a bath make them stand out?
When your dog gets wet, the water displaces and
liberates these organic volatile molecules from
the surface of the dogs fur, allowing them
to find their way right into your nose.
Another smell that often offends dog owners is kibble.
Kibble is made up of a cocktail of animal fats,
vitamins, and minerals bulked together
by a soy or wheat grain.
Now, dogs aren’t big time grain lovers,
so chemists were called in to figure out
how to attract them to the food.
Turns out the best way to make dogs eat something
is make that something smell disgusting.

To give you an example of their interesting
taste
and smell, dogs are attracted to aromas like
putrescine and cadaverine; molecules that forensic
scientists know as “the dead body smell.”

So you can see we’ve got a
little bit of a difference in taste.
So the challenge for chemists is finding
the right balance between attractive
eats and offensive odors.
You dog owners are being thought
of in a lab out there somewhere.
How comforting.
Finally, folks, a reminder: pick up your dog’s poop.
Here’s why: dogs add to zoonotic transfer
in public water– that’s how a scientists says that
animals can get people sick with the water we use.

A study recently found a way to track dog
poop
in the water supply, and found exactly what

they were looking for, dog poop
residue in the water supply.
This is trouble because dogs can carry
many different parasites including e-coli
which can contaminate water sources.
So seriously people, pick up your dog crap!
If you love watching dog videos, join the club.
And Hey! You can watch this one about
why Dogs smell each other’s butts.
Not a dog person? Shame on you.
But, It’s okay though, you can watch this
other video about the chemistry of cats.
Got a pet question?
We will more than likely have an answer
for you so post it down in the comments.
Subscribe on the way out, and
we’ll see you again soon.
